facts.text: Raja Bisheshwar Bux Singh was taluqdar of Oudh and succeeded to Gangwat Estate in 1925 on death of widow of last holder; estate governed by Oudh Estates Act I of 1869.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the courts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will. Of course this by itself gives no comfort to the defendant she has to establish,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of will as a whole reveals dominant intention to provide for Dhuj Singh and his personal heirs generation after generation without power of alienation, creating series of life estates; words like 'absolute owner' displaced by context, preamble, and restraint clause which is primary and not repugnant.

holdings.text: Section 14 of the Oudh Estates Act has no application where the legatee is given only a life interest and not absolute ownership.

anchor.surface_text: But section 14 would have noapplication if the disposition by the will did not make Dhuj Singh an absolute owner of the properties and he was given only an interest for life which was followed by subsequent interests created in favour of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 14 by its terms applies only where transferee/legatee gets same rights, powers, conditions, and succession rules as transferor/testator, implying absolute ownership; here will creates limited life interest.

holdings.text: The will validly creates successive life estates in favour of Dhuj Singh's existing personal heirs (including widow), with properties reverting to estate on failure of line.

anchor.surface_text: As it was the intention of the testator that the properties should remain intact till the line of Dhuj Singh was exhausted and each successor was to enjoy and hold the properties without any power of alienation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Testator's intent for intact properties for heirs successively without alienation; permitted under s.11 wide powers and s.12 (perpetuities); class gift to heirs valid pro tanto for those in existence at testator's death per Tagore v. Tagore.

holdings.text: Section 11 of the Oudh Estates Act confers wide powers on taluqdar to bequeath limited interests or future estates.

anchor.surface_text: Section. 11 of the Oudh Estates Act confers very wide powers of disposition upon a taluqdar and he is competent under the section to transfer the whole or any portion of his estate, or of his right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reading of s.11 allowing transfer or bequest of whole or portion during life or by will; supported by s.12 applying perpetuities rule indicating future estates contemplated.

holdings.text: Total restraint on alienation valid where it reflects primary intention consistent with limited estate, displacing absolute ownership presumption.

anchor.surface_text: The clause in the will imposing total restraint -on alienation is also a pointer in the same direction. In cases where the intention of the testator is to grant an absolute estate, an attempt to reduce

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restraints repelled only if repugnant to absolute estate grant; here restrictions primary and integral to tenor of will creating life estates.

holdings.text: Class gift to series of heirs does not fail entirely but valid for those in existence at testator's death.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of principle from Tagore v. Tagore: invalid only as to unborn, valid for existing class members.
